The Gallie cavalry, at least such part of it as was permanently attached to Cacsar's army, seems to have been organized in Roman fashion. It was divided into ‘turmae’ (vi. 8, 5 5 ; vii 45, 5 13 viii. 18, 55 a, 3), and had- Roman officers called ‘decuriones' (i. 23, 5 a). It was commanded as a whole, first by the young Publius Crassus (i. 52, 5 7), afterwards by C. Volusenus Quadratus, with the title of ‘praefectus equitum' (viii. 48‚5 13 cp. C. iii. 60, 5 4). This titleisalso bestowed on Quintus Atius Varus (viii. 28, 5 a), who may have been intermediate between the two.

The aid which Caesar derived from the Gauls was not confined to cavalry. He did not however count much on the Gallie infantry, regarding them as rather for show than for use ¹. At the time of the great revolt he called upon the Aedui for 10,ooo font-soldiers, which he got, but not for long (νῆ’ 3425 1)·
